abstract.p: Laurie Kretchmar letter on April 16 article on explosion of high-technology conmpanies and wealth in Israel; says article contends hundreds of affluent Israelis are suddenly willing to bankroll their brilliant newphews' computer doolings but nothing is mentioned about brilliant nieces (S)

block.p: Re ''The New Israel: Land of Milk and Money'' (April 16), which discussed the hot entrepreneurial climate for technology businesses and the consequent income gap in the country:
Re ''The New Israel: Land of Milk and Money'' (April 16), which discussed the hot entrepreneurial climate for technology businesses and the consequent income gap in the country:

The article noted that as a result of the great success of Mirabilis, the Israeli company that developed the ICQ instant messaging system and was later acquired by America Online, ''hundreds of affluent Israelis were suddenly willing to bankroll their brilliant nephews' computer doodlings.''
That's nice, but what about the brilliant nieces?

My three nieces and I (and countless others) would like to know how many Israeli women have started companies and how that compares with the United States where women are starting businesses at a faster rate than men and where the Internet has helped to level the playing field.
LAURIE KRETCHMAR San Mateo, Calif., April 18
The writer is a consultant to Internet businesses.
